Assignment on Module 5 :
Introduction to VR
CO5 : Analyze application of VR hardware and software components.
AIM : Create a report on the study of any one VR headset with respect to
following points
1. Introduction
The Meta Quest 3, also known simply as “Quest 3,” was announced in June 2023 and
officially released in October 2023 by Reality Labs, a division of Meta Platforms. It
represents Meta’s continued investment in virtual and mixed reality technologies and is the
successor to the popular Quest 2 headset.
The Quest 3 is the third-generation standalone VR headset in the Meta Quest series. It
merges the accessibility and affordability of the Quest 2 with advanced features from the
premium Quest Pro, such as pancake lenses and full-color mixed-reality passthr

ough.
These upgrades make the Quest 3 a powerful and compact device positioned as Meta’s
flagship mixed-reality (MR) headset for mainstream users.
The headset primarily targets consumers and gamers, offering immersive VR and MR
experiences without requiring a PC or external sensors. Beyond entertainment, it is also
being adopted in education, enterprise training, and fitness applications due to its
standalone functionality, ease of setup, and strong developer ecosystem supported by
Meta’s software tools.
2. Hardware Specifications
Specification Details
Display Type Dual LCD panels with Meta’s Infinite Display optical stack using
2-element pancake lenses. Marketed as “4K+ Infinite Display.”
Resolution 2064 × 2208 pixels per eye
Refresh Rate Supports 72 Hz, 90 Hz, and 120 Hz refresh rates
Field of View (FOV) Approximate 110° horizontal FOV.
Processor (SoC) Qualcomm Snapdragon XR2 Gen 2, upgraded from XR2 Gen 1 (Quest
2) . It offers significantly higher GPU and overall performance.
GPU In

tegrated Adreno GPU (part of XR2 Gen 2 SoC). It provides about 2×
graphics performance compared to XR2 Gen 1.
RAM & Storage 8 GB RAM available in 128 GB, 256 GB, and 512 GB storage variants .
Sensors Inside-out optical tracking with multiple outward cameras , IMU
(accelerometer + gyroscope) , RGB color passthrough cameras for MR.
IR cameras for controller tracking, supports eye-tracking via
SDK/firmware (hardware eye-tracking present mainly in higher-end
models).
3. Input and Interaction Devices
Controllers: Touch Plus controllers (tracked, ergonomic, with buttons, thumbsticks, and
advanced haptics). They are tracked by the headset’s inside-out optical system .
Hand tracking / gesture input: Native hand tracking supported (controller-less interactions
are available for many experiences).
Voice / eye control: Voice commands supported for system-level actions; eye-tracking
capabilities are being expanded in Meta’s platform and developer SDKs (Quest 3 supports
MR features that can use gaz

e heuristics, full native eye-tracking). Use of eye data is
exposed via SDKs where available.
Motion tracking tech: Inside-out tracking only i.e the headset uses outward-facing
cameras for simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) and controller tracking (no
external lighthouse/base stations).
4. Audio System
Speakers: Built-in spatial audio speakers (on-headset open-ear speakers) and standard
3.5 mm / USB-C options for external headphones.
Noise cancellation: There is no active noise cancellation like in ANC headphones; the
headset uses on-board speakers and passive isolation from the facial interface external
headphones are recommended when isolation/ANC is required.
3D / spatial audio: The system provides spatialized audio that follows head orientation and
in-world object positions, which significantly enhances immersion for games and MR
experiences (developers can use spatial audio APIs).
5. Display and Optics
The Meta Quest 3 features a 4K+ Infinite Display with a resolution of

2064 × 2208 pixels
per eye and advanced pancake lenses that enhance visual clarity while reducing headset
thickness. It supports refresh rates of 72 Hz, 90 Hz, and 120 Hz, offering a 110° horizontal
and 96° vertical field of view. Overall, it delivers a 30% resolution increase and 25% sharper
image quality compared to the Quest 2.
● Display:
○ Resolution: 2064 × 2208 pixels per eye (4K+ Infinite Display)
○ Pixels per inch (PPI): 1,218
○ Pixels per degree (PPD): 25
● Optics:
○ Lens Type: Pancake lens
○ Visual Clarity: 25% sharper center field view than Quest 2
○ Stray Light: Reduced glare and scattered light artifacts
○ Slimmer Profile: 40% thinner optic design than Quest 2
● Field of View (FOV):
○ Horizontal: 110°
○ Vertical: 96°
● Refresh Rate:
○ Supported Modes: 72 Hz, 90 Hz, 120 Hz
7. Software Ecosystem and Developer Tools
OS & Platforms: Runs Meta Horizon OS based on Android AOSP. Supports native Quest
apps and compatible Android apps.
SDKs / APIs: Developers can use Meta XR SDK a

nd Horizon OS SDK with Unity, Unreal
Engine, or OpenXR. Mixed-reality features are available via device SDKs such as v57+ for
Quest 3.
Developer Mode & Store: Developer mode allows testing and sideloading of apps. Apps
can be published on the Meta Quest Store or App Lab. The Meta XR Simulator enables
development without the headset.
App Development & Deployment: Developers create apps in Unity or Unreal, integrate
Meta XR or OpenXR plugins, test using the simulator or via Link/Air Link, build the APK,
and deploy to the headset or submit to the Quest Store. MR passthrough APIs enable
mixed-reality content.
8. Applications and Use Cases
● Gaming: Used for immersive VR and MR gaming with titles like Beat Saber, Asgard’s
Wrath 2, and Superhot VR. Supports PC VR games via Meta Link.
● Education & Training: Helps in medical, engineering, and military simulations, offering
interactive learning through apps like Wander and Prisms VR.
● Enterprise Collaboration: Enables virtual meetings and tea

mwork in 3D spaces using
Horizon Workrooms.
● Cloud gaming: Play Xbox games directly on the headset via Xbox Cloud Gaming.
● Mixed reality games: Play games that blend virtual elements with your physical
surroundings.
● Media consumption: Watch movies and shows on a large virtual screen from streaming
services like Netflix by using the browser, or download content to watch offline.
9.Market Analysis
Market Positioning & Availability:
Meta dominates the global consumer VR headset market with around 59% of XR shipments
in 2023. The Quest 3 is a mid-to-premium standalone VR/MR headset offering high-end
specs at a lower price than ultra-premium options. In India, adoption is slower due to high
import costs, limited availability, and lower disposable income.
Market Trends & Forecasts:
Global VR/AR headset shipments declined ~19% in 2023 due to cost pressures and limited
use cases, but Meta mitigated the drop with strong product strategy. Shipments are expected
to rebound by 2025–2028 as pri

ces fall and features improve. In India, the broader
metaverse hardware segment is forecast to grow at a ~40.8% CAGR (2024–2030), despite
hardware challenges.
Pricing, Competitors & Target Audience:
Meta introduced the Quest 3S to make mixed reality more accessible. Competitors include
Sony PSVR2, Apple Vision Pro, and lower-cost tethered/AR headsets. The target audience
includes gamers, VR enthusiasts, MR content creators, and households seeking standalone
immersive experiences.
10. Strengths and Limitations
Strengths
● Significant uplift in hardware: higher resolution displays, improved optics, and thinner
form factor compared to its predecessor.
● Excellent mixed-reality (MR) support: full-colour passthrough cameras and enhanced
tracking make blending real and virtual worlds much more seamless.
● Solid standalone capability: no PC or external sensors required for many VR
experiences, making setup easier for consumers.
● Backwards compatibility and wide ecosystem: supports apps from

prior generation, and
integrates well into the existing VR content store and ecosystem.
Limitations
● Battery life remains modest: stand-alone use often yields around ~2 hours or less of
active usage before needing recharge.
● Comfort and ergonomics concerns: the standard head strap and facial interface may not
be ideal for extended sessions without optional accessories.
● Mixed-reality capture/passthrough still has room for improvement: although much better
than earlier models, camera clarity and low-light performance aren’t top-tier compared to
ultra-premium headsets.
● Higher cost than entry-level headsets: the improved hardware comes at a premium price,
and accessories add further cost.
Subject in-charge
Ms Sonali Suryawanshi / Ms. Sharddha Sandimani
